title: Mrbluntzy
author: Mrbluntzy
content: Will Satoshi be happy about the idea of the government to adopt Bitcoin & using it as reserve? Sincerely I have had this thought come to my mind few times and I wanted to put it up here today to see what fellow Bitcoinist thinks. There are many more experience Bitcoinist here older than me in the game but for my best knowledge so far are in the quote down. QuoteCreation of Bitcoin in 2009 was a direct response to the 2008 financial crisis, offering a decentralized alternative to traditional financial systems. QuoteLaunching bitcoin was to create a peer to peer payment system which would be way better than all the existing forms of payment methods.QuoteThe digital currency was intended to provide an alternative payment system that would operate free of central control but otherwise be used just like traditional currencies. QuoteA decentralized form of digital cash that eliminates the need for traditional intermediaries like banks and governments.Now that financial institutions and government are becoming interested in Bitcoin, which we all know how this is going to look like on the future. They would want to take control. If Satoshi is still alive, how would he feel and what if he wakes up one day decides to do what I don't want to imagine about?

comments.author: Charles-Tim
comments.body: Quote from: Mrbluntzy on January 01, 2025, 02:15:02 PMWill Satoshi be happy about the idea of the government to adopt Bitcoin & using it as reserve? Why not? Satoshi did not want any control and he did not reveal his identity because of this. Government are not controlling bitcoin but controlling exchanges and other centralized platforms. Even bitcoin transaction till today is not controlled in a way that it is censored.Quote from: Mrbluntzy on January 01, 2025, 02:15:02 PMNow that financial institutions and government are becoming interested in Bitcoin, which we all know how this is going to look like on the future. They would want to take control. If Satoshi is still alive, how would he feel and what if he wakes up one day decides to do what I don't want to imagine about? Among what are truly decentralized, bitcoin is still part of them. Bitcoin is still peer-to-peer payment system. Bitcoin still eliminate central control. Satoshi did not design those exchanges and other central controls. It designed nodes, wallets and everything needed for bitcoin not to have central control. You can still make use of bitcoin like that. Let us wait and see what will happen in the future but bitcoin is not for the government to control.

comments.author: HeRetiK
comments.body: Not sure what Satoshi would have thought about government reserves; but I doubt Satoshi would have liked seeing Bitcoin ETFs happen given that these are a huge step backwards towards the initial problem of intermediaries and centralized control.Then again all of these are probably inevitable side effects of Bitcoin's success, with no middle-ground between Bitcoin succeeding the way we see now and Bitcoin fading into obscurity.

comments.author: Ambatman
comments.body: Bitcoin is the closest we have seen to true decentralization which I believe is probably impossible to have in the real world. Government and ETFs showing interest doesn't make it centralized.Yeah Bitcoin was created to remove intermediaries which still exists. It has changed People that subscribe to ETF are not buying Bitcoin but shares While the ETF are the ones buying the Bitcoin. Likewise CEX, they own the coins while you given a interface form of the coin.

comments.author: Hatchy
comments.body: Quote from: Mrbluntzy on January 01, 2025, 02:15:02 PMIf Satoshi is still alive, how would he feel and what if he wakes up one day decides to do what I don't want to imagine about? And what's that exactly mate? To shut down Bitcoin? If that's the case, you should know that Even Satoshi Nakamoto, the creator of Bitcoin would not be able to unilaterally make changes to the Bitcoin protocol without the acceptance and implementation of the changes by the Bitcoin Core developers. Bitcoin works using a consensus.. The government and other bigger institutions buying Bitcoin shouldn't be anything to fear of mate, thy cannot control Bitcoin because of its decentralized nature. Even if what we now have are more of the centralized systems, Bitcoin true decentralization is still very solid.

comments.author: BIT-BENDER
comments.body: Firstly Satoshi may not be dead, infact no one knows who Satoshi is but one thing I am sure is that Satoshi would be proud of what Bitcoin has achieved.I think he won't have a problem with government adopting it infact he or they should be happy because it would definitely generally increase the adoption level of Bitcoin.I don't think the battle is against the government but the battle is against financial system freedom and since government can't control Bitcoin I don't see any problem with them adopting it.

comments.author: Samlucky O
comments.body: Quote from: Mrbluntzy on January 01, 2025, 02:15:02 PMWill Satoshi be happy about the idea of the government to adopt Bitcoin & using it as reserve? its a capital NO. although the dream of Satoshi Sakamoto was for bitcoin to be use as an alternative to fiat or banking system, and he also knew that its growth will dependent upon massive adoption all over the world by demand and supply, but not to be controlled by some group of people especially government who will buy and  stacked like some bunch of wood, to be used up at any given time which eventually makes bitcoin not it purpose anymore. what he needed is a fair system whereby majority will have bitcoin but not for majority of the asset to be controlled by some entity. because if bitcoin is used as a reserve asset, majority of the coin will be held by the government and will be used to manipulate the market. although the price will surge high due to creating scarcity but will eventually dump the market if sold at once.

comments.author: Felicity_Tide
comments.body: Quote from: Mrbluntzy on January 01, 2025, 02:15:02 PMWill Satoshi be happy about the idea of the government to adopt Bitcoin & using it as reserve? Sincerely I have had this thought come to my mind few times and I wanted to put it up here today to see what fellow Bitcoinist thinks. There are many more experience Bitcoinist here older than me in the game but for my best knowledge so far are in the quote down. ~snipNow that financial institutions and government are becoming interested in Bitcoin, which we all know how this is going to look like on the future. They would want to take control. If Satoshi is still alive, how would he feel and what if he wakes up one day decides to do what I don't want to imagine about? Interesting question, but the truth is, there is nothing we can do about it. The government are very smart. After their long frown towards it, they've decided to embrace it because such technology looks promising and doesn't seem like the regular type. Fine, some of us are scared that the whole government involvement and reserve thing doesn't look genuine as it is, but I don't think the government will be able to take control of the technology itself.Though, having that purchasing power to buy a massive amount for reserve purposes looks threatening in terms of price manipulation, but I also feel that the government won't want to spend alot in something they can't control. There are so many points that can be raise from this if we to start analyzing. At the end of the day, Satoshi knows he has played his part for the community, by introducing the technology and making it decentralization. It's now the duty of the community members to play their own part because the government will surely need key figures to get things done.

comments.author: moneystery
comments.body: not sure what satoshi was thinking when he heard that governments were using bitcoin as a reserve currency. but his reaction to this should have been quite happy, meaning that governments are not cracking down on bitcoin, and people are still free to use it, and its value is increasing along with its adoption. even though governments are increasingly using bitcoin as a store of value rather than a digital currency (which was satoshi's goal), but at least there are still many people who use bitcoin as a digital currency in their transactions, meaning that the vision of bitcoin itself is still relevant and used by more people.

comments.author: aoluain
comments.body: Satoshi created a decentralised, deflationary, open source, 100% secure cryptocurrency and walked away leaving Bitcoin without its active creator and in so doing relinquished it to become what it is today.I'm sure the creator of the greatest financial tool of the 21st century and a master of anonymityhad the vision to see where it would end up provided it got the attention - which it has for the last 15 years.I believe he knew if it grew to where it is today that there would be institutional and governmental interest,it just makes sense that everyone should acquire Bitcoin, it was always just a matter of time - andstill is.

comments.author: Synchronice
comments.body: Quote from: Mrbluntzy on January 01, 2025, 02:15:02 PMWill Satoshi be happy about the idea of the government to adopt Bitcoin & using it as reserve? I think that he will be proud in a way that he created an innovation of the 21st century, something that started with a few people on this tiny forum and went viral on a level where governments are thinking about saving their strategic reserves in Bitcoin. This is a huge achievement for any person, so, I think that this way, he will be proud but it's a different subject if he likes the idea of governments using them. I think that he doesn't like because his purpose was to create a P2P payment method that would solve the issues that were in e-commerce business, he didn't create bitcoin for storing wealth for governments. Also, he had decentralization in his mind when he was creating Bitcoin but it's clear that governments are enemies of decentralization.

comments.author: BlackHatCoiner
comments.body: Quote from: Mrbluntzy on January 01, 2025, 02:15:02 PMWill Satoshi be happy about the idea of the government to adopt Bitcoin & using it as reserve?Proud perhaps, happy about the way things turned out, not so sure. I do think that bitcoin is just as it should be, a politically and nationally neutral asset, with the characteristics of hard money. But, I do sometimes suspect he was a true cypherpunk at heart and deliberately kept it hidden to avoid influencing its reputation.

comments.author: Stalker22
comments.body: I dont know what Satoshi would think about government wanted to use Bitcoin.  When he invented it, I doubt it even crossed his mind that could happen.  It probably seemed impossible to everyone at the time.  Its hard to predict his reaction.  He might be happy that Bitcoin got so big and important that even governments see value in it and  that would prove he achieved his goal of creating a decentralized payment system that doesnt rely on banks or governments.  But he also might hate the idea of governments getting involved at all since that goes against Bitcoins independant ethos.  Either way, I think Satoshi would be pretty shocked.  Even just a few years ago, Bitcoin was still seen as shady internet money for geeks.  Now world governments want in? Thats a huge change.  My guess is it looks really different than whatever he initially imagined.

comments.author: tabas
comments.body: I think he'd be more than pleased to see that the governments and financial institutions are adopting his project. At first, it's all for the community but the wide acceptance of it is unstoppable and it's going there. Maybe he had also envisioned this to come when the great crisis that had happened more than a decade ago, he probably thought that this time might come. Since it is free for everybody, then the includes these centralized communities and markets and so, governments and financial institutions adopting it is music to his ears.

comments.author: Justtoons
comments.body: Quote from: Justtoons on January 01, 2025, 11:15:21 PMQuote from: Mrbluntzy on January 01, 2025, 02:15:02 PMWill Satoshi be happy about the idea of the government to adopt Bitcoin & using it as reserve? Sincerely I have had this thought come to my mind few times and I wanted to put it up here today to see what fellow Bitcoinist thinks. There are many more experience Bitcoinist here older than me in the game but for my best knowledge so far are in the quote down. QuoteCreation of Bitcoin in 2009 was a direct response to the 2008 financial crisis, offering a decentralized alternative to traditional financial systems. QuoteLaunching bitcoin was to create a peer to peer payment system which would be way better than all the existing forms of payment methods.QuoteThe digital currency was intended to provide an alternative payment system that would operate free of central control but otherwise be used just like traditional currencies. QuoteA decentralized form of digital cash that eliminates the need for traditional intermediaries like banks and governments.Now that financial institutions and government are becoming interested in Bitcoin, which we all know how this is going to look like on the future. They would want to take control. If Satoshi is still alive, how would he feel and what if he wakes up one day decides to do what I don't want to imagine about? t's a good thought , Satoshi's goals were to create a better, more efficient payment system, not necessarily to prevent  all government interaction. Perhaps government adoption, even with its potential downsides, could be viewed as a testament to Bitcoin's success in achieving those initial goals.  It forces us to reconsider what true decentralization means in practice. Does it mean complete absence of interaction with governments, or does it mean a system resistant to complete control by any single entity? The debate is far from over, and the evolution of Bitcoin will continue to shape the answer

comments.author: icalical
comments.body: Sotoshi Nakamoto created Bitcoin as a decentralized currency, beyond the control of governments. Governments adopting Bitcoin is like the opposite of those ideas, and El Salvador making Bitcoin legal tender back in 2021. On the other hand, that means Bitcoin is gaining legitimacy, mainstream use. There recently has been talk that the US consideration might make Bitcoin a reserve, speaking to growing acceptance. As much as government involvement can raise the credibility of Bitcoin, it risks bringing back that central control Bitcoin which hardly the case since those governments still only own Bitcoin not controlling it. So, I think Satoshi will still be happy looking at how Bitcoin grow today.

comments.author: joniboini
comments.body: Quote from: Mrbluntzy on January 01, 2025, 02:15:02 PMIf Satoshi is still alive, how would he feel and what if he wakes up one day decides to do what I don't want to imagine about? What kind of thing are you referring to? Selling all his Bitcoin? Trying to encourage people to drop Bitcoin? Or what?Maybe the biggest "damage" he can cause is accelerating the bear market if he decides to sell his Bitcoin. Even that move is unlikely to discourage the government or people from speculating with Bitcoin at all. If anything it will allow whales to absorb the supply to make manipulation easier, no? I believe satoshi is not that naive. I also think that his goal is achieved already regardless of what the governments do. CMIIW.

comments.author: davis196
comments.body: Is Satoshi pleased with this? Probably not. Maybe he will come back and express his opinions about the current state of Bitcoin, but I don't believe that such thing would ever happen. He is most likely:1.Dead.2."Satoshi Nakamoto" was a team of developers and never a true person. Or maybe the conspiracy theory was right and the CIA created Bitcoin.Bitcoin was supposed to be anti-bank and anti-government, but at the end of the day, the banks and governments finally took control over it.Maybe this should serve as a lesson, that no decentralized currency could ever remain truly independent for a long time.
